document.title: Religion Curriculum 2014 Archdiocese of Seattle Catholic Schools

495AB66650D944F1A0A4A1B139F539B4.description:
Understand the meaning of monotheism and know which religions share this
belief.

AB8BB6B869F64BEA9B628B78A915FEA7.description:
Identify Judaism as Jesus’ faith and culture, and understand that those
responsible for Jesus’ death are those who rejected his teachings.

C95C7B53B74D4C6EBE066560B6A4CB60.description:
Name some of the communions of the Christian church that share the belief
of Baptism in the Triune God.

A085BE6587694291818B9FFD2402FC6A.description:
Identify ways to show respect for the various faith traditions and show
awareness that we respect others because God loves us all.

A04582D0499E48B095B2488471628F02.description: Recognize different Christian and non-Christian traditions.

0115EA501E7C484DA7C47793A379280A.description: Understand that people express their belief in God in different ways.

0341D14691AE4644B5F1F2A9C6582DEE.description:
CALL
TO ECUMENISM,
INTERFAITH
DIALOGUE AND THE
NEW
EVANGELIZATION

43D39E2A0FCD42A6B290ADCBF6B59E70.description: Give examples of how Christians can be “prophets” in society.

2F14493366274D9FB88249F216FF40C1.description:
Participate in service projects inspired from the Old Testament people who
demonstrated stewardship of creation.

56F94A530BAE4D208E4E46478ADB475C.description: Locate Old Testament people who worked for justice and the common good.

3DE511F6805B4969B0D15988629C4D9B.description: Reflect and pray to make good decisions that care for God's gifts.

A68A9135C5874904A47ED80C74AEB374.description:
CALL TO
STEWARDSHIP AND
SERVICE: Catholic
social teaching about
the common good
[2419-2422]

93B32231E74A4B14A6DDDDBB371DBE92.description:
Explore how Old Testament prophets resisted and then responded to God’s
call.

518E48BBDE994B54BEFBCC894EB85D69.description:
BAPTISMAL CALL AND
DISCIPLESHIP (the
mandate to go forth)
[816-849]
Scripture
Mt. 9:10-13; 28:16-20
Mk. 16:15-18
1 Sam. 3:1-10
1 Kings 3:4-15

83B2F8085DAF4CCEBC638C5F247A0009.description:
TASK OF CATECHESIS 6: THE CHURCH’S MISSIONARY LIFE AND SERVICE: Students acquire and demonstrate skills to recognize their gifts from God and their
vocation to share the good News of Jesus Christ in word and deed in the world.

BBB4CE1F925D46FB8BEBC7A13D71509C.description:
Name and describe some Old Testament people who modeled some of the
same qualities of Mary, e.g. Deborah, Hannah, Ruth, Esther, Sarah, Hannah, Noah,
Abraham, Moses, Joseph in Genesis. (See Scripture Recommendations.)

0D5930C642EA47579B09CFF4493DE868.description:
Recognize titles of Mary as she is celebrated throughout the liturgical
calendar.

4461BD2D3ABF4041B5F1E24723C4FE3F.description: Understand Mary as the first disciple and model of the Church.

476FCF951A1741FAAFFD220848EC8A1E.description:
MARY AS MODEL OF
CHURCH
[148-149, 963-975,
2673-2682]
Scripture
Lk. 1:26-55
Jn. 19:25-27

9C1973EC45F3485089023CCA53D5C294.description: Give examples of saints who lived out their covenant relationship with God.

3AD0BAD206DA400E8FB2C1C9F9A125AE.description: Celebrate the feast day of the parish patron saint.

820D3F98A53442C2BCBE6B96B09E9A9A.description: Define the following types of vocations: ordained; consecrated; lay faithful.

6FBEF6BB48AB4F45B593F2B4F45880C0.description:
Understand and explain how prayer helps us discern our vocation and
connect with calling stories from the Old Testament.

196B2545CC2A474CB46374279BAD5998.description:
VOCATION:
MARRIAGE,
PRIESTHOOD,
RELIGIOUS LIFE
[914-933]
Scripture
Gen. 12:1-9
Gen. 3:1-10

CC6D5A7E28BA4DD09B2815EF4FE5E010.description:
Identify and describe qualities of holy people from the Old Testament as
models for our lives.

0BA1F8AE557B432084A0976D636C4DF6.description:
THE
UNIVERSAL CALL TO
HOLINESS
[2013-2014,2028,2813]
Scripture
Lev. 11:44
Eph. 1:3-4; 4:1-6
Pet. 1:15-16

4E80CE1EE14241488B687BE1A93CC7F1.description:
Identify and examine examples of the domestic church in Old Testatment
stories.

EA5A5196872C4871B0AC7BE7DA02CD01.description:
The Domestic Church
[1655-58, 1666, 2204-
2257, 2685]
Scripture
Ex. 20:12
Mt. 15:4

61E18C8058F144C0ACB4E69DCE5226E0.description:
Identify priest, prophet and king leaders in the Old Testament and
associate them with lay ministries today.

305132CB2E6E41F5A6CB2A2F9BA20819.description: Name and explain how to follow the Precepts of the Church.

8D3629FA6B474B54B9FFE544E9F68699.description:
Identify roles of Old Testament leaders and associate them with the roles of
the Hierarchy/Magisterium, e.g. Abraham, Moses, Isaac.

7A5DAF63133A40718151179522C4AA71.description:
Church
Order: The HierarchyMagisterium
and
Infallibility
[874-896]
Scripture
Ex. 2:1-10; 24; 3:1-17;
12:1-28; 14: 5-29; 16:1-
35; 19:16-20:17; 24:1-12

4D437B0221D549F3A321C4387796CC44.description:
Find the relationship between the development of faith in the Old Testament
and the concept of apostolic tradition.

3E6356CC40B54FC9BA9DD372F7F3BD19.description:
Review that we are called to be part of the Church that is one, holy, catholic
and apostolic.

64AAFFBDE9644DB897E1D222F87DE49D.description:
THE
MYSTERY AND MARKS
OF THE CHURCH:
One, Holy, Catholic,
and Apostolic
[811-870]

F2E6D8DBBBDD4D70AD64A534DA2233B4.description:
Explain why we respect our body and the bodies of others because we are
all temples of the Holy Spirit.

86AAEBE2E9BF4EC1A5CF2FBED3AC901B.description:
Temple of
the Holy Spirit
[797-801]
Scripture
1 Cor 6:19-20

D0617CCBC69B4F158268B4EB6B053AE4.description:
Name and describe selected Old Testament women who inspire us to lead
holy lives: Deborah, Ruth, Esther.

C08AD6919A9842B1B75306BC14F4645F.description: Review the Catholic Church as a worldwide, apostolic community.

C0B99855DF3449559DC6A8BC7B1493B0.description: Explore the meaning of family and community in the Old Testament.

66FA128B939D4226A85EF86A699B814F.description:
Distinguish between the three images of the church: People of God, Body of
Christ, and Temple of the Holy Spirit.

C8796B52E48341138342012E4F9D4954.description:
Associate how Jewish traditions from the Old Testament provide the foundation
for Christianity.

1BB8E96377794051ADA2343894D19B4E.description: Review that we are called to be part of the Church.

4FD1DBCDF4674838A94EEFEEFD8C7074.description:
THE CHURCH
IN GOD’S PLAN
[748-780]
Church History
[758-780]

9277175ADB1E4B1F97A720F194D88B29.description:
TASK OF CATECHESIS 5: THE LIFE, COMMUNITY AND HISTORY OF THE CHURCH: Students study and participate in the life and mission of the church, the Body of
Christ and the community of believers, as expressed in the Church’s origin, history, ecclesiology, the Communion of Saints and their family, the domestic church.

D137DD1641DE402CBA563E52DFA71795.description: Agnus Dei / Behold the Lamb of God

6CEDFBDEA50E4310AAF4E8DBDE64B759.description: Responses after Scripture: Readings and Gospel

1329AD09AC434CE88888C8A1AB72175B.description: Spontaneous Prayer using “You, Who, Do Through” sequence

19E06EE7093D474CB7312F5A4CC154D3.description:
Invitatory, Psalm(s) antiphonal style and Doxology from the Liturgy of the Hours –
Psalm 95 and Canticle of Daniel (Dn 3:57-88)

4F97EBAB1079446D8A25867F5D3071E2.description: One or more decades of the Rosary

C67E16E64AF14F8DB6955B29804AD57C.description: Prayers of blessing, adoration, praise, intercession, thanksgiving, petition

91CE64F547A44F4CB835692AF4441E9E.description:
PRAYERS WE
KNOW BY HEART,
EXPERIENCE AND
SHARE AT MASS

9E2DF8189D95448FA40ADDD1B24E42F5.description:
Know and explain the Luminous Mysteries: Baptism of Jesus, Marriage Feast
at Cana, Jesus Announces the Kingdom of God, Last Supper. Find Scriptural references
to each.

D59D95F014944BBEBD31B3F0733DFA0D.description:
DEVOTIONAL
PRACTICES (e.g.
Rosary, Stations of the
Cross, Novenas)
[1200-1209, 1674-1679,
2683-2696]

48554483D57A4124A6EA6B5B49A8A8B2.description:
Identify instances of temptation in the Old Testament and how praying the Our
Father helps us when we are tempted.

7CC3D4B8890A409D9F3527CEDB283884.description:
Recite the “Our Father” and write about the requests we are making through the
prayer.

4D34DD8FAB1B4646B540F211B1B7590A.description:
OUR FATHER:
Summary of the Gospel
[2746-2865]
Scripture
Mt. 6:5-15
Lk. 11:1-13

D82384FD972944F6935CA2039AEA5F72.description: Participate in a variety of traditional devotions.

679A86E6C1A1412EAE25F93F7691F231.description: Engage in four stages of Lectio Divina.

7913D70B67574F1EAACDEB303B7A13A7.description:
EXPRESSIONS OF
PRAYER (vocal
meditation,
contemplation,
personal and share)
[2700-2724]

8710480128CA4E2CB4947A78476D96FC.description: Locate Old Testament passages which reference personal prayer

57992A72D4B54C20B67AACC9568D7B8C.description:
Know the Liturgy of the Hours is comprised of Psalms from the Old
Testament.

2CBCF64935564DF69BCE60A6BC9B6E10.description: Identify how prayer is a covenant relationship with God.

82F33C19F923420ABE8DF5B79BC9AA0D.description:
Recognize canticles in the Bible, e.g. Magnificat, Luke 1.46-55, A Song of the
Blessed, Matthew 5.3-1

7931620D78AB4281885ECCF2FB8A3630.description: Describe Moses as a great intercessor.

A7FC052F22D046AFBAF4A375B1C71D49.description:
Identify forms of prayer in the Old Testament: blessing, adoration, petition,
intercession, thanksgiving, and praise.

294412665F074555BB3EADE2F623E255.description:
FORMS OF PRAYER
(Blessing, Adoration
Petition, Intercession
Thanksgiving, Praise)
[2623-2649]
Scripture
Mt. 5:3-10
Lk. 1:46-55

6A0841D00FB44F42B5917AF6E769A3E7.description: Demonstrate ways to prepare for prayer.

9280CADCF2D641BDB81BDFB3BF210103.description:
Experience Lectio Divina as a model for praying the psalms, and prayed by
Catholics across the globe. (See Resources.)

441978F48DA246A7ACB9EF721F08F205.description:
Students prepare for prayer using the Psalms, the same prayer of Jesus and
his Apostles.

FF641714DB9244C29BD9720105DC3FB7.description:
THE UNIVERSAL
CALL TO PRAYER,
IMPORTANCE OF
PRAYER
[2558-2758]

6ABA80C6D2034BB3866A8D55800CCACC.description: TASK OF CATECHESIS 4 – TEACHING TO PRAY: Students experience and engage in Catholic expressions of prayer to deepen their relationship with God and the Church.

6745F65AE2E04A83A0492EAEAA175DF6.description:
Explain how the Works of Mercy are actions that answer God’s call to a
loving relationship with Him.

9E4CE72BD7D34B3EB15ACFCA40BC0DF9.description:
Relate the sacredness of all creation with the concept of stewardship in their
classroom, school, and parish.

32A992BE766C43D8B9EB20E8C0FE0142.description:
Practice care of personal belongings, classroom, school building, and parish
grounds.

9F0C86CA9903462CA9EAF344E584B3EF.description:
Recognize while reading Sacred Scripture, that we are called to encounter,
consider how we are called to change, and how we may respond to the encounter.

7CC0DE6B97954900B75A233152AF6B7D.description:
Using Scripture stories from the Old Testament (e.g. Ruth and Naomi)
students identify examples of those who lived out their responsibility to care for God’s
creation, the poor and vulnerable.

18EA59F4CB1F4B51B3528EBB707850FB.description:
Identify how the prophets called people to live with God given rights and
responsibilities.

604F0AAAF75A47CCB392F9C2EE960C69.description:
Explain the special place of human beings have as stewards of God’s
creation.

8E19C4730746481999286CE8D3A2CFC5.description:
Catholic
Social Teachings –
Consistent Ethic of
Life, Love of Neighbor,
and Corporal and
Spiritual Works of
Mercy
[2419-2449]
Scripture
Rth. 1:1-22; 3:1-4:17

76AC5434E8A947FD92C1711975C5BAB4.description:
Describe how Original Sin continues to affect us personally and in society
today.

F4F80EFD33B94C61AA3A79291760EEF0.description: Recognize the importance of praying for those who have died.

77AAB2885EA946FFA7452885E535B324.description:
Reflect on the second story of creation and understand that sin separates us
from God and one another.

38ED3F874CF14A2CB4789E83F2E2A031.description:
Identify and describe Old Testament passages that are examples of
personal and social sin

754D1BCED914479CBC54B2B54CCA004D.description:
Personal
and Social Sin
[1846-1876]
Scripture
Gen. 2-3
2 Mac. 12:38-46

B9A5B234B1A14B638598A604DDEF61AE.description: Explain why leaders in the Old Testament had a responsibility to act morally.

E165EC32519349098955CAEE06F84B56.description:
Reflect on the story of Cain and Abel to understand that we are our brother’s
keeper.

4F65DBA9D90E461792906D5D9895A009.description:
Connect each of the Cardinal and Theological Virtues with people from the
Old Testament.

2F34C7D3A8FE433CB8E219808692EA8E.description:
Be able to raise and share questions about suffering and promise in the Old
Testament and in the world today.

8EA8CFB725834503826DAAE730974EB5.description: Describe concrete ways to practice the Beatitudes.

46A78044213849649DBE0553AAF619AE.description: Explain how leading a virtuous/moral life has a communal impact.

C60A0B8D6F5145B19B903B024C8B136A.description:
Virtues:
Cardinal and
Theological
[1803-1845, 2656-2662]
Scripture
Lk. 1:26-38; 6:20-26
Mt. 18:21-35

23E4110292F84B82AD9EB6D5B2D6DED9.description:
Identify which of the Ten Commandments are examples of natural law and
which are God-given.

E06073B7D0754CA189E1B3307B6D00DA.description: Apply the Ten Commandments to situations in our lives.

42E1BFF44AD14C0DAC855EEA96E94F13.description:
Locate the Ten Commandments in the Old Testament and explain how these
apply to living a moral life.

DDE670DD1C5147D0A670674B3FE263E5.description:
Explore the stories of a covenant people who sometimes chose or failed to
choose the right relationship with God.

7DF8BA3275A749E4A0514E64249D6854.description: Compare and contrast covenant with civil law.

1A801F9A1A2F488180B556103DA48344.description:
Covenant
and the Ten
Commandments
[2052-2557]
Scripture
Ex. 19:16-20:17; 24:1-12
Mt. 22:34:-40
Mk. 12:28-34

598A367272364C77A44F158C7557C060.description:
Experience the Examen to deepen our awareness of how we follow Christ in
our daily lives. (See Resources.)

44FCE4D92B8A4EBB93986F35D5B66263.description: Locate Old Testament passages demonstrating the mercy of God.

7CA63BD8B1064434A7CFADA904A6DFA1.description:
Describe Old Testament passages where people chose to follow God or
chose to sin, e.g. Cain and Abel; Tower of Babel; Golden Calf; Ruth; Esther.

44128D4B26BD461B97F21110D3F93346.description:
Explain how the story of Cain and Abel demonstrates the wounded nature of
humanity and its effects.

9864205C4258417EBF8CF71810328618.description:
Give examples of suffering and promise in the Old Testament and in the world
today and understand how sin damages our ability to live within a covenant.

1054B1D2F2734983871E8B4AA703D875.description:
Describe the Fall and the sinfulness of humanity as Original Sin: a reality of
human existence.

92738554CDF84D23B3FA50546A293D1B.description:
Articulate how the development of conscience as an informed inner voice
that helps to distinguish between a morally good act or bad act.

A1F449E7E160468881559090996EF9A0.description:
State components of morally good: the desired action, the purpose or
intention for doing the action, and the circumstances for making the choices.

E3855EAFB5464FACAA432DE43574307D.description:
Human
Freedom and
Conscience Formation
[1030-1037, 1730-1803]
Scripture
Gn. 3:1-24; 4:1-6; 11:1-9
Ex. 3:1-7
Rth. 1:1-22; 3:1-4:17
Est. 4:12-30
Job 38:1-41

4938277058FF49D9A9A8FB768E262FC1.description:
Describe Old Testament people who found authentic happiness when
following God, e.g. Daniel in Lion’s Den; Joseph in Genesis; Noah; Abraham and Sarah.

0B87492046744C42B8AB0F545AEB11D6.description:
Compare and relate the Ten Commandments to the Beatitudes in the New
Testament.

0DD6A86DDC904E48916A8350A40C314D.description: Understand that we are called to reflect on our moral choices.

2C6271F8EC024838B2EE93D2B4BAD940.description: Give examples of treating yourself and others with respect.

1B7B814FFCBC4162A206E815C921B4A2.description: Associate the creation stories of humanity to the concept of human dignity.

B5389E3311774AFDA4756FC0999E3F5F.description: Articulate the message of the creation stories in the Bible.

5631B5E5AF84401E9BC565104D86A9DE.description:
Made in the
image of God –
Foundation of Human
Dignity
[355-368,1004,1700-
1876]
Scripture
Gn. 1:1-2:3

DA2E16E1C3DF49F8B8CDBA861FA90BFE.description:
Locate and cite passages from the Old Testament where people expressed a
capacity and desire (longing) for God.

A302780321054971AB88EF03E8F8C626.description:
TASK OF CATECHESIS 3 – MORAL EDUCATION: Students develop a moral conscience that is informed by Church teachings and conformed to Christ, as modeled in a
personal life of virtue and demonstrated in service of the Gospel’s demands for society.

D7B13EC7F72D49C0B3A79CA86834A302.description:
Locate and cite passages from the Old Testament found in the Book of
Catholic Household Blessings. (See Resources)

C12B198672F34B7398BDEFD0F1B18454.description:
Liturgical
Rites: Weddings,
[1621-1637], Funerals
[988-1029, 1680-1690]
and Blessings
[1671-1673]

16126394AF694F1E887104EF5FA625B0.description:
Antiphonally pray psalms from the Liturgy of the Hours including those
learned in previous grades, Psalm 95, and Canticle of Daniel.

D4ACD64C42CF4AECA62FB5F8223DD4A3.description:
Know the invitatory and opening refrains for Morning Prayer and Evening
Prayer and the Doxology used with the Liturgy of the Hours.

5506383E6CC54366A9DD1A97AE2D42E2.description:
Divine Office
Liturgy of the Hours
[1174-1178]
Scripture:
Psalm 139, 95
Dn. 3:57-88 - Canticle
of Daniel

F0AB28414D96456CABEF106E89148680.description:
Recognize several examples of sacramentals: holy water, crucifix, blessed
candles, Sign of the Cross, anointing with oil.

C8CD753A7192484DA52B87293B727191.description:
Research symbols and rituals of the Jewish tradition found in the Old
Testament and compare and contrast with our Catholic symbols and rituals.

806D315945CF4664A9220FA7A42EAF41.description: Know the definition and effects of sacramental – holy objects and actions.

8E27AF48F9154FF18A239ADE431DF106.description:
Liturgical
Symbols and
Sacramentals
[1179-1199, 1667-1679]
Scripture
Exodus

DCDFD3F8217A446CAC8B9BC2DA56D09C.description:
Compare, contrast, and apply the Exodus event to the events in the readings
and blessing of the baptismal water at the Easter Vigil Liturgy and the blessing of the
baptismal water at every baptism.

3675706CF90C4101B3A24E90748F6B89.description: Understand how the date for Easter is determined.

6E3BDD537BA74F55AA0276D9B2205C8D.description:
Understand the liturgical year as a call to repentance, reflection and
conversion, which are also expressed in the books of the Old Testament.

C2C45226816F46F884E10722740E795C.description:
Locate and cite stories describing marital fidelity that model God’s faithfulness in
the Old Testament: e.g., Sarah and Abraham, Song of Songs 2:6.

AB23A43C107C4EEEB3D9EBD6231CC6C2.description: Connect the sacrament of marriage to the second story of creation.

DD333D115B55463B810236488DFE0BB3.description:
Relate and apply Old Testament events to the Sacraments at the Service of
Communion – marriage and holy orders.

FD0334E8995649A6AEE7EE46B79B3E64.description:
Sacraments at
the Service of
Communion
[1533-1666]
Scripture
Gen. 15:1-21; 22:1-18
Song of Songs 2:6
Heb. 7:17-25

5B1532462AB94024A815FBBF41E23638.description: Identify psalms that express a desire for forgiveness of God’s mercy.

89DFE14D53264811AD874E475A20CD6C.description:
Describe how the story of Nathaniel challenging King David is a model of God’s
mercy. ( 2 Sam.)

1375B9BBC17F43848051CF33315A24EA.description:
Relate and apply Old Testament events to the Sacraments of Healing –
Penance/Reconciliation and Anointing of the Sick.

9C0EF087570846BA8DB19DADA7A0F257.description:
Participate fully in the sacrament of Penance/Reconciliation: examination of
conscience, confession, act of sorrow, resolution to not sin again, and absolution by a
priest.

C4A01E664BD5416F8A3B760BFE452CE6.description:
Sacraments of
Healing
[979-987, 1420-1484]
Scripture
Ex. 12:1-20
2 Sam 12: 7-15

4F557557A8D746AEAEBA57168955E21E.description:
Connect the Passover to Eucharist and the anointing of the Kings of Israel to
Confirmation.

1230D274F4A64DA49AF6F1A3272FB58B.description: Connect Baptism to Noah’s Ark and the Crossing of the Red Sea.

4F7CAE87C4EE40079F59E5FB95EC7D2E.description:
Sacraments of
Initiation
[966-977, 1212-1419]
Scripture
Ex. 12:1-20
Ex. 14:5-29; 16:1-35

6F69A632341A4FD9B47425B19244E6AC.description:
Review Old Testament stories that provide the foundations to the Sacraments
today.

41F5586C902843CAACE28DE7DB129D4A.description: Articulate how the Sacraments strengthen their relationship with the Triune God.

A40B720861724075B501DC2986720743.description: Explain what it means to live a life based on the sacraments.

904C118074F0450CAB6E82C5139A8DE9.description:
CELEBRATION
OF THE SEVEN
SACRAMENTS
[1210-1666]
Scripture
Gen. 6:9-9:17; 15:1-21
Ex. 16:1-35
Jn. 1:1-7; 6:32-58
1 Cor. 10:16-18
2 Cor. 4:1-6
1 Sam. 16:1-13

882423127E9346CD9932D9F6450717F3.description:
As a class, with guidance from the teacher, prepare a liturgy based on a chosen
theme or feast day, including choice of readings, creation of intercessory prayers, and
music.

B8EE0FB4D64B40FDA3A7EE1F2A86F37D.description:
Connect the themes from the Last Supper and the Eucharist to the sacrifices of
Abraham, Melchisedek, and Moses.

342226057EE34B97873D3AC16E23F97E.description:
Connect Lamb of God themes from the Passover story in Exodus, the Last
Supper and the Eucharist.

207A8A2516DE40E4AB01F97A189BCDF9.description: Recognize the cycle of readings in the Lectionary that is used at Mass.

267C87CB8A2841478155AF40C1D20528.description:
Recall when passages from the Old Testament are read during Mass (Liturgy of
the Word).

52FC98A260D548208297157DDE6D4678.description:
Explain the concept of transubstantiation and associate it with the Real
Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

0A613B6C730E49D49DA34900C541046B.description:
Understand the Liturgy of the Word and Liturgy of the Eucharist as central parts
of the Mass.

397D645FD3D64181A7AD2FD95D208D1E.description: Identify the principal parts of the Mass as well as prayers and actions in each part.

05A0EB8F404E4A3BB5233607ECF81AAB.description: Participate actively and prayerfully in Eucharistic liturgies.

F7DAED4E35F1470485EFBEDC3F2BCA57.description:
Eucharist
Who, how, when, and
where the Mass is
celebrated
[1135-1167, 1322-1419]
Scripture:
Gen. 15:1-21; 22:1-18
Ex. 2:1-10; 3:1-17; 12:1-
14; 20:3-11
Jn. 6:32:58
Heb. 7:1-28

E42F4DBBE1C54082B03CB0CF0ADF37D1.description:
TASK OF CATECHESIS 2 – LITURGICAL EDUCATION: Students recognize the presence of Christ and enter into communion with Him through active, full and conscious
participation in the Liturgical celebrations and Sacraments of the Church.

AF4D91855D854F9E8A46524016C0EF75.description:
Recall that faith is a gift that calls us to believe and to follow the teaching of our
Church.

DC4C9879C17944CB9080188993DBF724.description:
Understand our core belief in the Trinity, the One God of the Old and the New
Testament and Jesus, as the promised messiah/redeemer as core beliefs expressed in the
Creed.

536B5C9467A64099AB5A931B80B7F395.description:
Articulate how the Holy Spirit helps us understand God’s presence within each
person.

24DCF31CBEB14332820FE9D814DDBCAC.description: Describe how Jesus is always present with the Father.

513A5E953D7D4B7FBA13AB19B1A8248E.description: Describe how Jesus fulfills the promises made in the Old Testament.

9A7185287821462BB0460BA1A8F53FAF.description:
Identify the Three Persons of the Trinity in the creation story of the Old
Testament, Genesis 1: 1-5.

53B37823E39C4BDC9EC294746235969D.description:
TRINITY:
CREATOR,
REDEEMER,
SANCTIFIER
[249-324]
Scripture:
Gen. 1:1-31, 2:1-25

C80850F71AAF4A528EE4B3DBA34DF1AA.description:
Retell stories from the Old Testament in which God interacts with people to bring
them to new life.

F0AF919BDE9B4C8B841FCDA2E07B96C6.description: Describe how Jesus fulfills the promises made in the Old Testament (typology).

03FB52650CA6497BAC0025563DBEA9FC.description: Trace God’s promise of a Savior, from the Fall of Adam and Eve to King David.

C6967930926145329DF45F561057A704.description:
Examine Old Testament scripture passages where the Israelites chose or failed
to choose to be in right relationship with God, e.g. Exodus, Joshua, Judges, Ruth.

0B74BEBDDD644809808AF31464F4EE54.description:
Understand that the prophets formed God’s people in the hope of salvation of a
new and everlasting Covenant.

0BBE4BA030CB49F8BA76438FE4751621.description: Describe the Wisdom Books and the theme of human life.

66328CBB950E47CDB19E24508015FC70.description: Describe the meaning behind the facts in the Historic Books.

6B6717CE76654BA9BB9E278404BA0FB9.description:
Compare, contrast the Exodus events to the readings and blessing of the
Baptismal water during the Easter Vigil.

C8D4CA78CAC44077BBE504E4FAE2F150.description:
Recount the story and theme of the Journey to the Promised Land; describe the
importance of Moses, the Law – the Ten Commandments, and the Covenant as guidelines
to moral living and freedom.

C9C4E0DCE4D74112A545250C6A72134F.description:
Identify instances of suffering and the promise of a redeemer in the Old
Testament: e.g. Moses, Joseph.

8C5A2550077942E29ACB38AFBE2BA2C2.description:
Explain the covenant relationship of Old Testament is foundational to the
Christian faith.

3BCEAF9B1C494AABAA544A8D109104D6.description:
Name the categories of the Old Testament as Pentateuch, Historic, Wisdom or
Prophets and locate where each can be found in the Bible.

A58C39E8A7C14D1880E3AE985663DA76.description: Know the names of the 46 books and categories of the Old Testament.

93C50C8DDAE04549A8FA1C15CA4CBFEF.description:
Identify psalms that are part of the Liturgy of the Hours, morning and evening
prayers.

B81CD4DF4285411083F679FE045417DB.description:
Learn and articulate how the “Word of God” is revealed in Scripture and
through Jesus in the Incarnation, “Word made flesh”.

626CEE219A2947969D8692645A596625.description:
Understand that by apostolic tradition the Church discerned which books are
included in the Bible.

51EA99E125BA4C9E9E720E5A97767F17.description:
Understand the concepts of inerrancy, Canon of Scripture and inspiration of
the Holy Spirit with Sacred Scripture.

A491C00ECBDD45CC8FFE3B16020820A5.description:
Recall the transmission of divine revelation that continues through apostolic
tradition.

0C8D03B7259E47C5B147CC1E450FD5FF.description:
Locate and cite passages in the Old Testament that highlight God’s desire to
reveal Himself to us.

EBB8A55391DE41D5BCFEE3DBB21FECB3.description: Recall and explain the concept of natural law.

FEA439177A564124998F2A17DADFDD2B.description:
TASK OF CATECHESIS 1 – KNOWLEDGE OF THE FAITH: Students explore, profess and reflect on our Catholic faith, which is the content of God’s revelation found in
Sacred Scripture and Sacred Tradition and lived out in the Creed and Church doctrine.
